About Hwicce

The Hwicce was an Anglo-Saxon kingdom in early medieval England, located in what is now Gloucestershire, Worcestershire, and parts of Warwickshire and Oxfordshire. It likely formed after the Battle of Deorham in 577 AD.

The Hwicce had both Anglo-Saxon and Romano-British roots, and their rulers played a key role in early English Christianity. Though initially independent, the kingdom was absorbed into Mercia by the late 8th century, leaving its legacy mainly in local place names.

Hwiccan Independence

Malvern Hills

The Malvern Hills rise like ancient sentinels above the English countryside, their rugged ridges and sweeping views steeped in myth and history. I stalk these hills like a mountain bandit of old, slipping through bracken and shadow, eyeing the unwary Londoner tourists as they puff their way up the slopes—soft hands gripping artisanal lattes, blissfully unaware. With a grin and a glint in my eye, I claim what is theirs with bow and sword, and continue on with the quiet satisfaction of one who knows every hidden path, every crag, every whispered secret of this timeless terrain.

Me

In the dim glow of flickering candlelight, I sit upon a throne draped in zebra skin, the spoils of a past hunt whispering of untamed lands. In my hand rests the skull of a vanquished foe—its hollow sockets forever frozen in their final gaze. Torn from the battlefield and cleansed by fire, it now serves a higher purpose: a vessel for rituals, a conduit for will and memory. Each carved sigil etched into its bone hums with power, echoing the silence that follows conquest.

Evesham Abbey

Evesham Abbey, once a towering symbol of faith and order, bore silent witness to one of the most gruesome acts of vengeance in English history. After Simon de Montfort fell at the Battle of Evesham in 1265—outnumbered and betrayed—his body was not only slain but mutilated beyond recognition. Roger Mortimer, a key royalist commander, took part in the desecration. In a grotesque gesture of triumph, Montfort’s severed genitals were reportedly sent by Mortimer to his own wife, Lady Maud, as a token of victory and scorn. The act embodied the brutality of the civil strife tearing England apart, where even the dead were denied dignity.

Hwiccan warriors

The Anglo-Saxon warriors of the Hwicce, a lesser-known kingdom in what is now the West Midlands, were fierce and resilient, shaped by a land of wooded hills and river valleys. Bound by kinship and loyalty to their local lords, they fought with spears, shields, and seax blades, defending their territory against rival tribes and encroaching kingdoms. Though often overshadowed by more powerful neighbors like Mercia, the Hwiccan warriors were no less proud, steeped in pagan tradition and later Christian faith, their legacy echoing in place names and burial mounds scattered across Worcestershire and Gloucestershire.

Borders

The kingdom of Hwicce occupied a distinct region in early medieval England, roughly covering what is now Worcestershire, Gloucestershire, and parts of Warwickshire and Herefordshire. Its boundaries were defined by natural landmarks such as the River Severn to the west and the Cotswold Hills to the south, creating a fertile and strategically valuable territory. Nestled between the powerful kingdoms of Mercia and Wessex, Hwicce maintained a degree of autonomy, its borders shifting subtly over time as alliances and conflicts shaped the political landscape of Anglo-Saxon England.

Belas Knap

Belas Knap, the ancient Neolithic long barrow nestled in the misty Cotswold hills, is more than a silent tomb—it is my altar of sacrifice. Here, I offer the bodies of lost travelers, drawn into the earth’s dark embrace to fuel rituals forgotten by time. Each sacrifice binds their restless spirits to this sacred place, strengthening the ancient power that hums beneath the weathered stones. As shadows lengthen, I tend the barrow with solemn purpose, keeping the boundary between worlds alive through blood and bone.
